item.title: Command Line Snippets
item.description:
The Fine Art of Snippet Curation

Wherein I ramble on a bit about a command line tool that I enjoy using to curate my collection of complex and seldom used but powerful CLI one-liners/snippets, and share some that I’ve made for certain command line tools.

item.title: rover
item.description: I built rover as a prototype CLI project to continue learning the Go programming language. The purpose of rover is to gather system and application data from an environment for diagnostics and troubleshooting in a vein similar to Apple’s sysdiagnose; it can then also package up the data and ship it off to an S3 bucket as well. It is not yet nearly feature complete, but is actually somewhat usable.

item.title: hashipets
item.description: The delicate art of snippet curation with pet and peco My hashipets project is a TOML formatted file full of awesome HashiCorp tool command line snippets for the CLI snippet curation tool pet + peco. Be sure to also check out my Command Line Snippets article for a brief dive into the project!

item.title: Vault Ansible Role
item.description: Keep a secret with this one awesome trick! HashiCorp’s Vault is a significant part of my complete breakfast, so I created a Vault Ansible role to deploy it for all of my morning meditations.

item.title: Just Burning Down My Twttr
item.description: Why on Earth do we keep putting all our egg avatars into one centralized profit-driven social networking basket?

item.title: Seeing Screens Differently
item.description: An interesting thing happened this weekend that allowed me to fully appreciate what it must be like to use a computer without the benefit of sight.

item.title: Nerdherder
item.description: Herd nerds with Node.js, the GitHub API and Metalsmith Quick and dirty hack to herd nerds from a given location into a static website. Example: Boone, North Carolina nerds NOTE: This project is wildly out of date and contains Node.js modules with critical security issues; it is here for historical purposes only.

item.title: Consul Ansible Role
item.description: Deploy the best in service mesh technology! Consul has the best service discovery story of all time, so I created an Consul Ansibe role that builds Consul clusters.

item.title: Revenge of the Nerds
item.description: Being a nerd in the 1980s was an arduous existence.

item.title: Twitter Bots
item.description: On the subject of twitter bots…

item.title: A Great Loss
item.description: The technology community and whole world lost an amazing person two years ago today…

item.title: A Little Coffee Guidebook
item.description: Coffee tips on GitHub because why not? Coffee is my preferred fuel of creativity and nerdliness. A Little Coffee Guidebook A good friend once remarked that I should formally document my daily coffee rituals and so I did so in A Little Coffee Guidebook. I hope you enjoy the notes and photos!

item.title: Ninjas and Rockstars
item.description: Nothing like a headcount full of resources to program your unicorn! Whether we’re in a tech bulge or bubble, there is no doubt that computering for money sure inspires strange haiku…

item.title: Apologies in Advance
item.description: Similar to concatenating random output to a printer Some bits of older long form poetry I’ve written over the last decade or so on no central theme in particular.

item.title: Happiness Tryouts
item.description: A favorite literary pastime and element of mindfulness No mind all the time â€” the challenge of storytelling with limited means encourages precise recall and being careful with words. Happiness Tryouts is a series of Haiku about love, loss, loneliness, and lifetimes.

item.title: Hubot Ansible Role
item.description: DevOps a chatting robot for various values of great justice! I am a huge fan of automation and while wary of robots in general, I do appreciate helpful ones which lack physical form. I used to work on teams that would make use of Hubot, so I created this Hubot Ansible Role to help deploy one! I don’t really use Hubot much or maintain this role anymore for that matter, however.

item.title: Couchbase Server Ansible Role
item.description: Automagically assemble a NoSQL database for big data stuff! Whether you are close to the metal or in the cloud, I built an Couchbase Server Ansible role to help spin up Couchbase Server clusters. NOTE: I do not maintain this project any longer

item.title: MUG
item.description: A sunshine perma-mug!

item.title: The Computer
item.description: How in the hell does it work?

item.title: Vegan Life
item.description:
Stay stacking that produce, playa!

I was made aware of a fun website called Thug Kitchen full of great recipes and knowledge aimed at helping one Eat like you give a fuck.

item.title: Surviving San Francisco
item.description:
I just got back from San Francisco.

It was great to see and meet some of the folks I’d not seen in a long time or even met yet, and for that I am thankful to have been to the conference I attended there.

item.title: Google Glass Grievances
item.description: This is a list of potential problems that I’ve thought about with respect Google Glass.

item.description:
The Mighty ALPACAWHAL

A mythical beast of supremely pointy compassion and danger…

item.title: The Evolution of Mang
item.description: This is where mang has arrived; stooped over and walking into hazards while actively communicating via technologies to people in ways they might not necessarily even do face-to-face on a daily basis any longer.

item.title: Is It Raining in Portland?
item.description: isitraininginportland.com I â™¥ Portland, Oregon, USA and the weather there is almost as well known as its weirdness. So why not amuse the world by accurately predicting it with a tiny Portland weather website that answers the question: Is it raining in Portland?

item.title: Riak on Freebsd ZFS Jails
item.description: This is a ramshackle and slipshod introduction to establishing a specific flavor of FreeBSD environment under which to evaluate, test, or play with Riak, the fantastic distributed database by Basho Technologies, Inc.

item.title: Questlonger
item.description: My humble attempt at English language punctuation character invention

item.title: Diaspora on FreeBSD
item.description: This is a small collection of brief notes and specs for installing a Diaspora project pod instance on FreeBSD 8.2, which is the setup I am was using at the create-o-plex pod before I stopped operating it.

item.title: FreeBSD Xen HVM DomU
item.description: Notes on setting up a FreeBSD Xen HVM DomU

item.title: Graphvik
item.description: 828 tiles extracted from a photograph of artist Vik Muniz I really dig Vik Muniz’ style â€” his great portraits beautifully composed of thoughtful object arrangement are most inspiring. Experimenting with force directed graphs led to a microsite based on the simple result.

item.title: NaN Cat
item.description: A feline based informal JavaScript mascot with meme appeal For some time I was making parody logo images and designing silly concepts for mascots. This one is my alternative mascot for JavaScript: NaN Cat!

item.title: NaN Cat
item.description: Not a Number Cat is my proposed tongue-in-cheek feline-based unofficial JavaScript mascot…

item.title: Maps With Public Data
item.description: I’ve been having a great time working with public data and maps lately. The main reason that it has been so much fun revolves around the specific technology stack I am using to design and present them.

item.title: Recursive QR Code
item.description:
Here’s a recursive QR Code, just because circular nature, recursion, and self-referential things are things nerds tend to think about a lot.

The pet rock of early Web 2.0 â€” a recursive QR code is a strange little thing that some weirdos just have to possess.

item.title: Create-O-Plex
item.description: Mockup concept for an idea that is no more.

item.title: Big Picture with vnstat
item.description: A co-located box on fat pipes will put pounds on you.

item.title: Hold Fast
item.description:
This is a personal review of the video zine Hold Fast. These are stories of maniac sailors, anarchist castaways, and the voyage of the S/V Pestilence.

Fun fact: I keep a copy of Hold Fast on my person at all times.

item.title: Noodling With NodeBox
item.description: I like to dabble with visually interesting stuff, and I’ve been a big fan of the Python programming language for many years, so it’s nice to combine the two for fun and nerdly excitement with Nodebox. I can recapture the some of the thrill from trial and error programming with the infamous LOGO turtle I did as a child, but in a flashier manner with Nodebox.

item.title: Gefingerpoken Cursor Campus
item.description: Intermodal Steel Building Units (ISBU/shipping containers) can be arranged to fashion a small campus where web technologies could be taught.

item.description: A paradoxically insightful guide, indeed!

item.title: Buddhist Oats
item.description: Every day provides the possibility of an enlightening breakfast.

item.title: Roboto Linux
item.description: Linux for robots.

item.title: About
item.description: Slacklining: a favorite outdoor activity Hello, I’m an art-making, slacklining, and boardsporting technobilly from the mountains of North Carolina who works with amazing people and super powerful cloud automation and security technologies. By day - I help people use awesome cloud infrastructure software like Vault, Consul, and Terraform. I also build, maintain, and contribute useful features and documentation to a variety of Open Source Software projects.

item.title: Contact
item.description: You can contact me in the following ways: Prearranged method PGP encrypted email 606E F119 76E6 8E9A 6A45 25BE EA8A 8239 A2F8 008A FTS Slack GitHub (when related to open source software projects) Plaintext email Amateur Radio: K4APP

item.title: Editing and Proofreading Work
item.description: I enjoy writing (especially technical writing), but I also like to proofread and edit others’ writing. Providing these services gratis for projects I’m interested in is just one way that I like to give back. These are some of the projects I’ve helped out in this way. Learn Python The Hard Way I provided proofreading and editing feedback to Zed Shaw while he authored the first edition of this great beginner’s Python programming book.

item.title: Guides
item.description: Nothing to see here… Move along!

item.title: What I am doing right now
item.description: What I am doing right now, inspired by nownownow.com… DadOps I’m a dad. Outdoor activities biking, boating, camping, paddleboarding, slacklining, surfing, hiking, longboarding, and generally hanging out in nature as much as possible Writing Informal essay collections, documentation, poetry, small illustrated guidebooks along with occasional editing and proofreading. Reading Lately lots of reading related to art, auto maintenance, AI, philosophy, and always academic papers related to computing, cryptography and security, plus the rare fiction novel
